awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Bone Adaptation-Driven Design of Scaffolds with Spatially-Varying Architecture for Enhanced Growth
awd_abstract_narration:
Synthetic bone scaffolds are porous inserts used to repair bone defects that would not otherwise heal on their own, providing mechanical support while allowing bone regeneration inside the pores.  Among the biocompatible materials used for their fabrication, calcium phosphate ceramics (CaPs) have received significant attention because their stiffness is similar to that of bone. The material system considered in this project consists of CaP scaffolds made by Direct Ink Writing, an additive manufacturing technique whereby rods of a colloidal ink are deposited in alternating layers and subsequently sintered.  An outstanding challenge in the clinical use of these scaffolds is the lack of complete integration of the bone into the scaffold pores.  Complete osteointegration is hindered by two limitations in existing scaffold design methods: they only consider scaffolds made of straight rods, and they are not directly driven by a measure of bone integration.  This award supports fundamental research to formulate the first computational framework for the design of patient-specific CaP scaffolds made of curvilinear rods and driven by bone adaptation.  Results of this research have the potential to substantially increase the clinical viability of synthetic scaffolds for large defect repair, with tangible and significant treatment and financial benefits for patients.  In addition to bone scaffolds, this research will advance design methodology that may be applied to related material systems, such as architected porous surfaces in orthopedic implants, scaffolds for cell tissue culture, particulate filters and self-healing materials. A summer exchange of undergraduate and graduate students between the two collaborating institutions will provide training opportunities for the next generation of material designers. This award will also support outreach to high school students via summer residential camps. 

To achieve the goal of formulating the first computational design methodology for patient-specific bone scaffolds with spatially-varying architecture for complete bone regeneration, this project will couple topology optimization techniques with bone adaptation simulation. In particular, this project will 1) formulate a framework to simultaneously model bone adaptation within the bone-scaffold system while readily accommodating changes in the scaffold design; 2) incorporate adequate measures of osteointegration and scaffold strength to incorporate as design criteria; and 3) formulate a design representation of the scaffold architecture that allows for local property control while ensuring manufacturability. The computational design framework will be validated via material and mechanical characterization of scaffolds designed, and via an in vivo study in pigs.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research is to formulate computational methods to design man-made, porous bone implants with intricate internal structures that allow bone to regrow and a bone injury to completely heal.  These implants aim to replace bone grafts, which are pieces of bone from the patient or a donor, that a surgeon uses to repair bone defects caused by tumors, injuries, birth defects, and disease.  Grafts from the patient or a donor work the best; however, they have important disadvantages such as the need for additional surgery, limited availability, or the possibility of rejection by the body.  To overcome these problems, researchers are pursuing the replacement of bone grafts with porous man-made implants, called bone scaffolds.

A significant barrier to the adoption of bone scaffolds in the clinic is that they often do not completely heal the bone defect, which can cause additional pain and suffering for the patient.  Advances in additive manufacturing techniques for some ceramic materials that are biocompatible and thus are not rejected by the body, and that have mechanical properties like those of bone, are making it possible to fabricate scaffolds with carefully designed porous structures. Modern techniques can fabricate bone scaffolds that are only a few millimeters in overall size and that have pores and internal features with sizes in the order of tens of microns; these dimensions are similar to those of the porous bone naturally present in bone grafts. These advances have opened the door to the design of bone scaffolds with internal structures that are tailored to each individual patient. Controlling the shape of the porous internal structure of the scaffolds through design and manufacturing allows the scaffolds to have regions with higher porosity that allow for flow of the nutrients that promote bone growth, and regions with lower porosity but higher stiffness to support the forces experienced by the bone.

This research produced computational techniques to efficiently design additively manufactured ceramic bone scaffolds with superior bone growth. Existing scaffold design techniques consider the bone scaffold to be a homogeneous material and their goal is to match the mechanical properties of bone. An important contribution of the work here is to instead design a scaffold tailored to each patient by considering the shape and location of the bone defect and the forces experienced by the that patient. Our techniques thus consider an inhomogeneous design of the porous scaffold structure, where the shape of the internal features and the pore size may vary in different regions of the scaffold. Moreover, our computational design techniques incorporate a computer simulation of bone growth inside the scaffold over time, and the goal of the design is to maximize bone growth. Another key aspect of our computational framework is that it imposes requirements on the design that ensure the scaffold can be fabricated with direct ink writing, the manufacturing process used to fabricate the ceramic scaffolds in our work. In vivo studies were conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed computational design techniques. In these studies, scaffold designs produced by our computational methods were fabricated and implanted in pig jaws. The scaffolds were later removed and imaged using high resolution computerized axial tomography (CAT) scans combined with an artificial intelligence-based approach developed here to assess the ingrown bone.

This project supported two doctoral students and their publications.


Last Modified: 02/12/2023
Modified by: Julian Norato
